Symptoms(Critical_stage): High blood sugar, Increased thirst and/or hunger, Blurred vision
Treatment(general): Keep your blood glucose levels as near to normal as possible by following a diet plan, taking prescribed medication and increasing your activity level.
Treatment(babies/infants): You can help your child prevent diabetes type -1 complications by: Working with your child to maintain good blood sugar control as much as possible, Teaching your child the importance of eating a healthy diet and participating in regular physical activity and scheduling regular visits with your child's diabetes health care professional.
Facts_or_Myths: Diabetics can consume sugar
Prevention: Good diet and exercise
FAQ: What should my blood sugar be?
FAQ Answers: A blood glucose range of 80-130 before meals and less than 180 about 2 hours after a meal. This range should place your A1c under 7.

Symptoms(female): Frequent yeast infections or urinary tract infections
Treatment(general): Maintain your blood cholesterol and triglyceride levels
Facts_or_Myths: Facts: Adults with diabetes have a two- to three-fold increased risk of heart attacks and strokes
Prevention: Quitting smoking and alcohol
FAQ: What is an A1c?
FAQ Answers: A Hemoglobin A1c is a 2-3 month average of your blood sugars. The recommended A1c is less than 7

Symptoms(common): Numbness or tingling in the hands or feet
Treatment(general): Control your blood pressure
Facts_or_Myths: Facts: Combined with reduced blood flow, neuropathy (nerve damage) in the feet increases the chance of foot ulcers, infection and eventual need for limb amputation.
Prevention: Resistance exercise
FAQ: What is Diabetes Mellites? How do you get it?
FAQ Answers: A high level of glucose in the blood is called diabetes.

Treatment(general): Exercising regularly and Losing weight
Treatment(critical_stage): Bariatric surgery is an option if you have Type 2 diabetes, are obese (body mass index over 35) and considered a good candidate for this type of surgery.
Facts_or_Myths: Facts: Diabetic retinopathy is an important cause of blindness, and occurs as a result of long-term accumulated damage to the small blood vessels in the retina.
Survival_Rate: outlook and life expectancy with brittle diabetes include : Complications, such as problems with the eyes, kidneys, heart and nerves, Frequent hospitalizations, Problems with pregnancy, Shorter life expectancy.
Prevention: Limited inactivity
FAQ: How to manage Diabetes?
FAQ Answers: The most important part of managing diabetes is your diet

Treatment(general): Type 1 diabetes: If you have this type, you must take insulin every day. Your pancreas no longer makes insulin.
Treatment(critical_stage): If your blood sugar is too high, you'll receive: Intravenous fluids, Supplements of phosphate, sodium, and potassium, Insulin
Facts_or_Myths: Facts: Diabetes is among the leading causes of kidney failure
Prevention: Lower your stress. Learn relaxation techniques, deep breathing exercises, mindful meditation, yoga and other helpful strategies.
FAQ: Â What can I do to prevent Diabetes?
FAQ Answers: The prevention of diabetes requires physical efforts every day,

Treatment(general): Type 2 diabetes: If you have this type, your treatments can include medications (both for diabetes and for conditions that are risk factors for diabetes), insulin and lifestyle changes such as losing weight, making healthy food choices and being more physically active.
Treatment(critical_stage): If your blood sugar is too low, you will receive: Glucagon (a hormone to increase blood sugar), Intravenous fluids, 50% dextrose solution.
Prevention: Prevent dehydration and keep skin hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids.
Diagnosis: screening for early signs of diabetes-related kidney disease and treatment.
FAQ: What are the complications of Diabetes Mellitus?
FAQ Answers: iabetes Mellitus can affect your kidney heart eyes and nerves

Treatment(general): ketoacidosis treatment include Blood glucose test, Basic metabolic panel, Ketone testing, Arterial blood gas, Osmolality blood test, Prescribing oral or IV antibiotics to control and eliminate infection.
Treatment(critical_stage): Main treatments for more advanced diabetic retinopathy are: laser treatment, injections of medication into your eyes, an operation to remove blood or scar tissue from your eye
Prevention: To reduce  risk of diabetes-related foot pain Checking your feet every day for any changes, Don't forget to look between your toes, Keeping your toenails trimmed and filed. Cut them straight across to prevent ingrown toenails, Washing your feet every day in warm water, not hot. Dry them thoroughly afterward, including between the toes. Then apply lotion to the tops and bottoms of the feet, but not between the toes, controlling your blood sugar, blood pressure and cholesterol levels,taking your diabetes medicine as prescribed, maintaining a healthy weight, eating a healthy, balanced diet, exercising regularly and stopping smoking.
Diagnosis: Fasting plasma glucose test, Random plasma glucose test
FAQ: How common are diabetes-related foot conditions?
FAQ Answers: The chance that a person with diabetes will develop a foot condition at some time in their life is about 15%.

Treatment(general): Diabetes treated by Continuous glucose monitor, Insulin pump,Islet cell transplantation, Pancreas transplant
Prevention: To reduce  risk of diabetes-related foot pain Getting your feet checked at every visit with a healthcare provider.
FAQ: What is the outlook for people with diabetes-related foot conditions?
FAQ Answers: The outlook depends on factors such as: How early the wound was found, Presence of infection and how much it spreads, Treatment effectiveness. If the infection can't be controlled and spreads too far, amputation may be necessary.

Symptoms(Critical_stage): High blood glucose (blood sugar) levels (over 250 mg/dL)
Diagnosis: Oral glucose tolerance test, Gestational diabetes tests, Gestational diabetes
FAQ: When should I seek medical care for diabetes-related foot pain?
FAQ Answers: Any changes in foot shape, Any changes to the skin on the feet, including a wound, redness or darkness, warmth or a funny smell, Hair loss on your toes, feet or legs, Loss of feeling in the toes, feet or legs, Pain, tingling, burning or cramping in the feet or legs, Thick, yellow toenails.

Symptoms(common): Fast heart rate, Pale skin, Restless sleep
Diagnosis: Glucose challenge test and Glucose tolerance test
FAQ: What is diabetes?
FAQ Answers: Diabetes happens when your body isn't able to take up sugar (glucose) into its cells and use it for energy. This results in a build up of extra sugar in your bloodstream.

Diagnosis: Examine your toes, feet and legs for diabetes-related foot conditions
FAQ: What are the different types of diabetes?
FAQ Answers: Type 1 diabetes, Type 2 diabetes, Prediabetes, Gestational diabetes, Monogenic diabetes syndromes, Cystic fibrosis-related diabetes, Drug or chemical-induced diabetes, Diabetes insipidus

Diagnosis: Touch the toes, feet and legs with various tools to check whether you have numbness  for diabetes-related foot conditions
FAQ: How common is diabetes?
FAQ Answers: The number of people who are diagnosed with diabetes increases with age. More than 26% of adults age 65 and older (about 1 in 4) have diabetes.

Diagnosis: Examine it for any signs of infection, such as redness, swelling, warmth, discoloration or discharge for diabetes-related foot conditions
FAQ: Who gets diabetes? What are the risk factors?
FAQ Answers: Risk factors for Type 1 diabetes include:  Having a family history, njury to the pancreas, Physical stress, Presence of autoantibodies, Exposure to illnesses caused by viruses .   Risk factors for prediabetes and Type 2 diabetes include: Being overweight, Having high blood pressure, Having low HDL cholesterol and high triglyceride level, Being physically inactive, Being age 45 or older, Having gestational diabetes or giving birth to a baby weighing more than 9 pounds, Having polycystic ovary syndrome., Being a smoker

FAQ: What happens if my blood glucose level is low?
FAQ Answers: Having a blood glucose level that is lower than the normal range (usually below 70 mg/dL) is called hypoglycemia. And you might experience Weakness or shaking.Moist skin, sweating, Dizziness, Sudden hunger.

FAQ: What happens if my blood glucose level is high?
FAQ Answers: If you have too much glucose in your blood, you have a condition called hyperglycemia.

FAQ: What insulin medications are approved to treat diabetes?
FAQ Answers: Rapid-acting insulins, Short-acting insulins, Intermediate-acting insulins, Long-acting insulins.

FAQ: How is insulin taken? How many different ways are there to take insulin?
FAQ Answers: Needle and syringe, Insulin pen, Insulin pump, Artificial pancreas, Insulin inhaler, Insulin injection port, Jet injector

FAQ: When is it necessary to call a doctor if you have diabetes?
FAQ Answers: If you have diabetes and your blood sugar is 300 mg/dL or higher two times in a row for an unknown reason,  If you have a low blood sugar (less than 70 mg/dL) that has not come up after three treatments

FAQ: How can I treat and manage hyperglycemia?
FAQ Answers: People with both type 1 and type 2 diabetes can manage hyperglycemia by eating healthy, being active, and managing stress.

FAQ: How do I prevent hyperglycemia?
FAQ Answers: Exercise to help lower blood sugar, Follow your meal plan if you have one, Maintain a healthy weight, Don't smoke, Limit drinking alcohol.

FAQ: What is brittle diabetes?
FAQ Answers: Brittle diabetes is diabetes that's especially difficult to manage and often disrupts everyday life. People with brittle diabetes have severe swings in blood glucose (blood sugar).

FAQ: How common is brittle diabetes?
FAQ Answers: Brittle diabetes is rare. It affects only about 3 of every 1,000 people with insulin-dependent diabetes.

FAQ: How can people with brittle diabetes care for themselves?
FAQ Answers: Eat a healthy diet low in sugar and carbohydrates to lessen swings in blood glucose, Exercise regularly, Maintain a healthy weight, Take diabetes medications exactly as prescribed, Test blood glucose frequently.

FAQ: When should I seek medical attention for brittle diabetes?
FAQ Answers: Confusion or dizziness, Fast heart rate, Trouble breathing, Vomiting.

FAQ: How diabetes can affect the eyes
FAQ Answers: a persistently high blood sugar level can damage these blood vessels in 3 main stages: background retinopathy, pre-proliferative retinopathy, proliferative retinopathy

FAQ: Am I at risk of diabetic retinopathy?
FAQ Answers: if you have had diabetes for a long time, have a persistently high blood sugar (blood glucose) level, have high blood pressure, have high cholesterol, are pregnant

FAQ: Type 1 diabetes in children
FAQ Answers: Type 1 diabetes in children is a condition in which your child's body no longer produces an important hormone (insulin). Your child needs insulin to survive, so the missing insulin needs to be replaced with injections or with an insulin pump.

FAQ: Type 2 diabetes in children
FAQ Answers: Type 2 diabetes in children is a chronic disease that affects the way your child's body processes sugar (glucose) for fuel. Without treatment, the disorder causes sugar to build up in the bloodstream, which can lead to serious long-term consequences.

FAQ: Type 2 diabetes in children causes?
FAQ Answers: increasing number of children with obesity has led to more cases of type 2 diabetes in younger people.

FAQ: Complications of Type - 2 diabetes in children?
FAQ Answers: Type 2 diabetes can affect nearly every organ in your child's body, including the blood vessels, nerves, eyes and kidneys.Â

Medication(general): Antibiotics are beneficial in certain types of acute diarrhea, they are usually not used except in specific situations. Over the counter drug Â Â Â Pepto-Bismol ( Bismuth subsalicylate ) , or anti-motility drug Imodium plus ( Â Â Â Loperamide hydrochloride with simethicone ) are few of medicines for diarrhea.
Treatment(general): Drink fluids :Â It is important to drink plenty of fluids to avoid dehydration
Expenses: IPD cases, the median out-of-pocket health expenditure for the management of one episode of diarrheal illness was Rs. 6385 (IQR: Rs. 5889) ranged from Rs. 2652ÂRs. 24,299
Facts_or_Myths: Myth 1: Diarrhea medicine will bung me up and delay my recovery from viral diarrhea
Prevention: Wash your hands often
Diagnosis: Stool studies including culture and other tests.Â This test checks for any abnormal bacteria in your digestive tract that may cause diarrhea and other problems. To do this, a small stool sample is taken and sent to a lab.
FAQ: What is diarrhea?
FAQ Answers: Diarrhea is an intestinal disorder characterized by abnormal fluidity and frequency of fecal evacuations, generally the result of increased motility in the colon; may be an important symptom of such underlying disorders as dysenteric diseases, lactose intolerance, GI tumors, and inflammatory bowel disease. Diarrhea is the passage of watery stools. This means body fluids and salts can be quickly lost from the body. The child becomes dry (dehydrated) and this is very dangerous and may kill the child.

Treatment(general): Oral Rehydration Solution Â (ORS) :Â ORS should be used to prevent dehydration. Standard home solutions such as salted rice water, salted yoghurt drinks, vegetable and chicken soups with salt can be given.Â
Expenses: CMC, Vellore, reported a figure of Rs. 6634 as cost of hospitalization for one episode of diarrhea in nonprofit referral hospital and Rs. 6071 in a private hospital. The figure for government hospitals was much less, i.e., Rs. 233
Facts_or_Myths: Myth 2: As soon as the diarrhea finishes I'm no longer infectious
Prevention: Not eating any fresh or raw fruits and vegetables unless you wash and peel them yourself
Diagnosis: Fasting tests.Â These tests show if you are unable to digest certain foods (food intolerance). They can also tell if certain foods bring on an immune system reaction (food allergy).
FAQ: Why is diarrhea dangerous?
FAQ Answers: When a person gets diarrhea, the body begins to lose a lot of water and salts - both of which are necessary for life. If the water and salts are not replaced fast, the body starts to "dry up" or get dehydrated. Severe dehydration can cause death.

Symptoms(common): Leaking stool and not being able to control your bowels (incontinence)
Treatment(general): Medications: Antibiotics are beneficial in certain types of acute diarrhea, they are usually not used except in specific situations. Over the counter drug Â Â Â Pepto-Bismol ( Bismuth subsalicylate ) , or anti-motility drug Imodium plus ( Â Â Â Loperamide hydrochloride with simethicone ) are few of medicines for diarrhea.
Facts_or_Myths: Myth 3: If I have bloody diarrhea I must have cancer
Prevention: Eat foods that have been cleaned and cooked in a safe way
Diagnosis: Blood tests.Â These can look forÂ metabolic problems like thyroid disease, anemia (low blood count), evidence of low vitamin levels suggesting poor absorption, and celiac disease, among other things.
FAQ: What is dehydration?
FAQ Answers:
Dehydration is the loss of water and body salts through diarrhea. The human body needs water to maintain enough blood and other fluids to function properly. If your body loses substantially more fluids than you are drinking, you become dehydrated. You may lose fluids in a variety of ways:

when urinating
when you vomit or have diarrhea
when sweating
from the lungs during normal breathing.
Along with the fluids, your body also loses electrolytes, which are salts normally found in blood, other fluids, and cells.

Treatment(general): Eating :Â WHO recommends a child with diarrhea should continue to be fed. Continued feeding speeds the recovery of normal intestinal function.
Facts_or_Myths: Myth 4: My viral diarrhea will stop sooner if I donÂt eat
Prevention: Not take any foods or liquids that may have been infected with a bacteria or virus
Diagnosis: Imaging tests.Â These tests can see if there are any problems with the way your organs are formed (structural abnormalities).
FAQ: How does dehydration occur?
FAQ Answers:
The usual causes of dehydration are a lot of diarrhea and vomiting. Dehydration can also occur if you do not eat or drink much during an illness or if you do not drink enough during or after strenuous exercise. Medications that cause fluid loss to control excess body fluid (diuretics) are a common long-term cause. Although anyone can become dehydrated, those who become dehydrated the most easily are:

babies under 1 year old
the elderly
anyone who has a fever

Symptoms(common): Urgent need to go to the bathroom
Facts_or_Myths: Myth 5: Flat lemonade will sort out my diarrhea
Prevention: Not drinking tap water or using it to brush your teeth

Facts_or_Myths: Fact 1: A significant proportion of diarrheal disease can be prevented through safe drinking-water and adequate sanitation and hygiene.
Fact 2: Globally, there are nearly 1.7 billion cases of childhood diarrheal disease every year.
Fact 3: Diarrhea is a leading cause of malnutrition in children under five years old.
Fact 4: Dehydaration is a serious risk
Fact 5: Drugs can cause diarrhea

Symptoms(common): Upper RTI :Cough, Fever, Hoarse voice, Fatigue and lack of energy, Red eyes,Runny nose, Sore throat, Swollen lymph nodes (swelling on the sides of your neck)
Symptoms(babies/infants): Upper RTI :Bronchiolitis, an infection that causes wheezing and coughing
Symptoms(old people): Upper RTI :Nasal congestion, Sneezing, Mucus production
Symptoms(Critical_stage): Upper RTI : Loss of consciousness, High fever (higher than 103 F)
Treatment(general): Upper RTI : You can most likely treat the symptoms at home through pain relievers
Prevention: Upper RTI : Avoid being in close contact with people who are sick.
FAQ: Upper RTI : What is an upper respiratory infection?
FAQ Answers:
Upper RTI : These infections affect your sinuses and throat. Upper respiratory infections include:
Common cold.Epiglottitis.Laryngitis.Pharyngitis (sore throat).Sinusitis (sinus infection).

Symptoms(common): Lower RTI : Congestion or runny nose, Dry cough, Sore throat, Low-grade fever, Mild headache
Symptoms(Critical_stage): Upper RTI : Rapid breathing or difficulty breathing
Treatment(general): Upper RTI : rest and drink fluids
Prevention: Upper RTI : Cover your mouth and nose if you're the one who's sick.
FAQ: Upper RTI : What causes upper respiratory infections?
FAQ Answers: Upper RTI : You get an upper respiratory infection when a virus (or bacteria) enters your respiratory system. For example, you might touch an infected surface or shake hands with a person whoÂs sick. You then touch your mouth, nose or eyes. The germs from your hands enter and infect your body.

Treatment(general): Upper RTI : If you have a bacterial infection, such as strep throat, you'll take antibiotics.
Prevention: Lower RTI : wash hands frequently
Diagnosis: Upper RTI : Nasal swab, Throat swab.
FAQ: Upper RTI : WhoÂs at risk for upper respiratory infections?
FAQ Answers:
These infections are common, and anyone can catch one. Yet certain groups of people are more at risk of catching infections. Children are at a high risk since they are often with other children who may be carrying a virus. Children may also wash their hands less frequently than adults. Plus, theyÂre more likely to put their fingers in their eyes, nose and mouth, allowing the germs to spread easily.
People who have heart or lung problems are also at higher risk of getting an upper respiratory infection. Those who have weak immune systems (due to another disease) may get more severe infections.

Treatment(general): Lower RTI : Intravenous fluids, Humidified oxygen
Prevention: Lower RTI : avoiding touching the face with unwashed hands
FAQ: Upper RTI : How are upper respiratory infections diagnosed?
FAQ Answers:
Upper RTI : Your healthcare provider may diagnose the infection based on a physical exam and your symptoms. TheyÂll look in your nose, ears and throat and listen to your chest to examine your breathing. You often donÂt need other tests.
If your provider is concerned you may have a lung infection or another infection, you may need : Lung (chest) X-ray,Lung CT scan,Lung (pulmonary) function test to see how your lungs are working.Nasal swab,Throat swab.Sputum test, when you cough up some sputum (phlegm from your lungs) for examination.

Symptoms(babies/infants): Upper RTI : Pink eye, an eye infection
Symptoms(Critical_stage): Lower RTI : Fever, Severe cough, Rapid breathing or difficulty breathing, Chest pain or tightness, Wheezing
Treatment(general): Lower RTI : Ventilation support
Prevention: Lower RTI : staying away from people with respiratory symptoms
FAQ: Upper RTI : Are upper respiratory infections contagious?
FAQ Answers:
Upper RTI : Yes, upper respiratory infections are contagious. They pass from person to person through respiratory droplets or hand-to-hand contact. People who have an upper respiratory infection can pass it to others through:Sneezing or coughing without covering their nose and mouth. This sprays germs into the air. Other people can breathe in those germ-filled droplets.
Sneezing or coughing into their hand and then touching someone elseÂs hand. The droplets are now on the other personÂs hand. When that person touches their nose, mouth or eyes, the infection enters their body.

Prevention: Lower RTI : cleaning and disinfecting surfaces regularly
Diagnosis: Lower RTI : Laboratory Tests: a sample of sputum or mucus is taken and inspected in a laboratory for the presence of bacterial organisms.
FAQ: Upper RTI : What are the symptoms of upper respiratory infections?
FAQ Answers: Upper RTI : You may get symptoms, including:Cough,Fever,Hoarse voice,Fatigue and lack of energy,Red eyes,Runny nose,Sore throat,Swollen lymph nodes (swelling on the sides of your neck).

Prevention: Lower RTI : getting vaccines
FAQ: Upper RTI : How long do upper respiratory infections last?
FAQ Answers: Upper RTI : Upper respiratory infections typically last one to two weeks. Most of the time, they go away on their own. Over-the-counter pain medications can help you feel better. Make sure you drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated.If your symptoms last longer than two weeks, talk to your healthcare provider. You may have another condition that is causing the symptoms, such as pneumonia or bronchitis.

Prevention: Lower RTI : getting a flu shot every year
FAQ: Upper RTI : Can antibiotics treat upper respiratory infections?
FAQ Answers: Upper RTI : Most of the time, viruses cause upper respiratory infections. Viruses donÂt respond to antibiotics. You can most likely treat the symptoms at home through pain relievers, rest and drinking fluids. If you have a bacterial infection, such as strep throat, youÂll take antibiotics. Penicillin or amoxicillin are frequently prescribed for strep throat.

Prevention: Lower RTI : avoiding known irritants, such as chemicals, fumes, and tobacco
FAQ: Upper RTI : When should I see a healthcare provider for an upper respiratory infection?
FAQ Answers:
Upper RTI : If you have any of these symptoms, contact your healthcare provider or seek medical help:
Loss of consciousness,High fever (higher than 103 F),Rapid breathing or difficulty breathing,Frequent, severe coughing, which may come with vomiting,Wheezing, a high-pitched whistling sound when you breathe out,Dizziness,Retractions, when you see a deeper outline of your ribcage or ribs than you normally do. (This sign may be more obvious in children).
Stridor, a harsh raspy vibrating when you breathe in that sometimes sounds like a seal. (Stridor is more common in children than adults).

FAQ: Upper RTI : Is the flu an upper respiratory infection?
FAQ Answers: Upper RTI : Influenza, or the flu, isnÂt considered an upper respiratory infection. ThatÂs because itÂs systemic Â it affects more than one system in the body. It usually affects the upper and lower respiratory system. The cold and flu have similar symptoms.

FAQ: Upper RTI : Is pneumonia an upper respiratory infection?
FAQ Answers: Upper RTI : Pneumonia is a lung infection. Symptoms can resemble those of an upper respiratory infection. You may have a severe cough that brings up phlegm (mucus), shortness of breath and chest pain. See your healthcare provider if you think you may have pneumonia.

FAQ: Upper RTI : How can I prevent upper respiratory infections?
FAQ Answers:
Upper RTI : Keep you and your family healthy. Take steps to prevent upper respiratory infections:
Practice good hygiene:
Wash hands, especially before eating or preparing food,Sneeze and cough into your arm or a tissue and wash hands after Live a healthy lifestyle:
Avoid contact with people who are sick,Drink plenty of fluids,Get enough sleep,Stop smoking, See your provider:
Keep up with routine checkups and immunizations.
Ask your provider if you should get the pneumococcal vaccine, which prevents pneumonia.
Call your healthcare provider if you have symptoms lasting longer than two weeks, a high fever or any other concern.

FAQ: Upper RTI : Should I worry about an upper respiratory infection?
FAQ Answers: Upper RTI : Most of the time, these infections go away on their own. YouÂll likely make a full recovery. However, some higher-risk groups should take extra precautions when it comes to upper respiratory infections. These infections can be more dangerous for:Children, especially babies,Older adults,People with immune system disordersIf you are in a high-risk group and get a cold or other respiratory infection, contact your healthcare provider.

FAQ: Upper RTI : What complications can happen from upper respiratory infections?
FAQ Answers: Upper RTI : Severe complications can include respiratory failure when thereÂs too much carbon dioxide in your blood. The infection could also spread to other parts of your body, such as your brain or heart. If you have any concerns about your symptoms, call your healthcare provider. If you are having trouble breathing or other worrisome symptoms, call 911 or head to the nearest ER.

FAQ: Lower RTI : What Is a Lower Respiratory Tract Infection?
FAQ Answers: Lower RTI :Lower Respiratory Tract Infections (LRTI) are infections that affect the airways (below the level of the larynx), including the trachea and the alveolar sacs.

FAQ: Lower RTI : Types of lower respiratory infections
FAQ Answers:
Lower RTI :Lower respiratory tract infections include:
bronchitis ,pneumonia ,bronchiolitis ,tuberculosis

FAQ: Lower RTI : Causes of lower respiratory infections
FAQ Answers:
Lower RTI :The number one cause of lower respiratory tract infections are viruses that invade the respiratory tract. Bacteria are the next most common cause. 

In bronchitis, the most common viruses are influenza (Âthe fluÂ) and the rhinovirus (which causes the common cold). 
The most common cause of pneumonia varies by age, but it can be due to a virus or bacteria. 
The most common causes of bronchiolitis are rhinovirus, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), and human metapneumovirus. 
More recently, SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19) can cause lower respiratory tract infections and sometimes lead to pneumonia.

FAQ: Lower RTI : Symptoms of lower respiratory infections
FAQ Answers:
Common symptoms of all lower respiratory tract infections are cough, fever, and shortness of breath. Depending on the type of illness, your age, and other medical problems, these symptoms can range from mild to severe. 

The symptoms of bronchitis include cough, muscular chest pain, fatigue, and mild shortness of breath. A bronchitis cough can be dry or bring up mucus. The cough usually lasts 1-3 weeks and is the last symptom to go away. Bronchitis symptoms are often mild enough to be treated at home. But, in a person with a lung condition like asthma or COPD, it can lead to a severe illness needing hospitalization. Older age, having a weaker immune system, and smoking increase the chances of severe illness. 

The symptoms of pneumonia are fever, cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain. A viral pneumonia has a more dry cough (without mucus), and the symptoms tend to be mild to moderate. Bacterial pneumonia is more likely to cause more severe symptoms, such as fever and cough with mucus. Viral pneumonia tends to go away on its own, while bacterial pneumonia gets worse without antibiotic treatment. 

People 5 years and older can get a type of pneumonia called Âwalking pneumonia,Â where symptoms are dry cough, muscle aches, and fatigue. The name Âwalking pneumoniaÂ comes from the fact that most people have mild to moderate symptoms and are able to walk around. 

Bronchiolitis usually starts as a common cold in the first 2-3 days. Symptoms include nasal congestion, runny nose, cough, and, sometimes, a fever. On days 3-5, the illness will reach its peak severity. At this stage, a child may start breathing faster than normal, using their rib and neck muscles to breathe, and having trouble feeding and playing. If these symptoms happen, the child needs to be seen by a doctor immediately.

FAQ: Lower RTI : Diagnosing and treating lower respiratory tract infections
FAQ Answers:
Lower RTI :In most cases, lower respiratory tract infections can be diagnosed clinically. This means that a healthcare provider can make the diagnosis by asking about your symptoms and listening to your lungs. More testing or imaging is not always needed. That said, a chest X-ray may be needed to diagnose pneumonia when listening to the lungs on a physical exam may not be enough. 

In some cases, nasal swabs that detect respiratory viruses can be done to find the cause of the lower respiratory tract infection. Because viral testing is expensive and does not usually change treatment, a nasal swab is not typically done.

FAQ: Lower RTI : Lower respiratory infections vs. upper respiratory infections
FAQ Answers: Lower RTI :The difference between lower respiratory tract infections and upper respiratory tract infections is the location of the infection and symptoms. The upper respiratory tract is made up of the nose, sinuses, throat, and voice box. Symptoms of upper respiratory tract infections include sneezing, runny nose, sore throat, and sinus pressure. Like lower respiratory infections, upper respiratory tract infections are mostly caused by viruses.

Medication(general): Isolate yourself in a well ventilated room.
Expenses: Rs 8,000-10,000 per day (including PPE and medicines)
Facts_or_Myths: Heat can stop coronavirus disease
Survival_Rate: In general mortality rate of the COVID 19 was 11.5%

FAQ: What is Covid 19?
FAQ Answers: COVID-19 is a disease caused by a virus called SARS-CoV-2. Most people with COVID-19 have mild symptoms, but some people become severely ill.

Medication(general): Use a triple layer medical mask, discard mask after 8 hours of use or earlier if they become wet or visibly soiled. In the event of a caregiver entering the room, both caregiver and patient may consider using N 95 mask.

FAQ: How does the Virus Spread?
FAQ Answers: 1.Breathing in air when close to an infected person who is exhaling small droplets and particles that contain the virus.2.Having these small droplets and particles that contain virus land on the eyes, nose, or mouth, especially through splashes and sprays like a cough or sneeze.3.Touching eyes, nose, or mouth with hands that have the virus on them.

Symptoms(common): Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Medication(general): Mask should be discarded only after disinfecting it with 1% Sodium Hypochlorite.
Treatment(critical_stage): require hospitalization, with treatment that might include antivirals such as remdesivir
Facts_or_Myths: COVID 19 Kills
Prevention: Choose open, well-ventilated spaces over closed ones. Open a window if indoors.
Diagnosis: Laboratory tests can take days to complete and include RT-PCR and other types of NAATs.
FAQ: What is Community Spread?
FAQ Answers: Community spread means people have been infected with the virus in an area, including some who are not sure how or where they became infected.

Medication(general): Take rest and drink a lot of fluids to maintain adequate hydration.
Facts_or_Myths: Drinking alcohol Cures COVID 19
Prevention: Take rest and drink a lot of fluids to maintain adequate hydration.
Diagnosis: An antibody test (also known as a serology test) can detect antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 in your blood.
FAQ: How can I Protect Myself?
FAQ Answers: Wear a Mask, Maintain Social Distance, Sanitize your hands

Medication(general): Follow respiratory etiquettes at all times.

FAQ: What is an N95 filtering facepiece respirator (FFR)?
FAQ Answers: An N95 FFR is a type of respirator which removes particles from the air that are breathed through it. These respirators filter out at least 95% of very small (0.3 micron) particles. N95 FFRs are capable of filtering out all types of particles, including bacteria and viruses.

FAQ: Is dengue contagious from person to person?
FAQ Answers: No, dengue is not contagious and cannot be spread merely by person to person contact. The dengue virus is carried and transmitted by mosquitoes. If a mosquito bites someone with dengue, and then bites another person, the second person can get infected. This is usually how dengue spreads and can sometimes become an epidemic.

Medication(general): Do not take ibuprofen, aspirin, or aspirin-containing drugs.

FAQ: Can I be infected with dengue a second or more times?
FAQ Answers: Yes. Dengue is caused by four different viral strains and infection with one virus does not protect a person against infection from the other three strains. Hence one can be infected by dengue four times. Subsequent infections increase the risk for the most serious forms of dengue, such as dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome.

FAQ: Â Is dengue a deadly disease? Can one die from dengue fever?
FAQ Answers: Although dengue fever is a serious and often painful condition, it is not a deadly disease and does not lead to death. With proper care, most people infected with dengue usually make a full recovery unless complications occur. These complications may include Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF) and Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS). In some of these cases death can occur but is rare. With proper care and treatment, even patients with DHF or DSS can make a full recovery. Hospitalization is highly recommended in cases of DHF or DSS and greatly increases the chances of survival.
